headline.main: Cernan Quits as Head Of Air One, New Carrier

results.snippet: Eugene A. Cernan, the former astronaut, has resigned as chairman of the board of Air One, a new airline that began flying out of St.  Louis at the beginning of April and caters mostly to business travelers.   Paul J. Rodgers, who had been president...
results.lead_paragraph: Eugene A. Cernan, the former astronaut, has resigned as chairman of the board of Air One, a new airline that began flying out of St. Louis at the beginning of April and caters mostly to business travelers. Paul J. Rodgers, who had been president and chief executive, has taken over as chairman. Mr. Cernan, who was commander of the Apollo 17 space mission to the moon, joined Air One in June 1981, working on the start-up of the airline.

results.snippet: To the Editor:    Turnabout being fair play, it is fitting for me, as an educator, to give a grade to the recent series of studies evaluating the public school system. Whereas ''Diagnosis of the Problem'' qualifies for an A-, the ''Prescription for...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Turnabout being fair play, it is fitting for me, as an educator, to give a grade to the recent series of studies evaluating the public school system. Whereas ''Diagnosis of the Problem'' qualifies for an A-, the ''Prescription for Solving the Problem'' deserves an F; overall grade, D+. It cannot be denied that the public school system in large measure is rooted in the past, is ever becoming more obsolete and functions nowhere near as efficiently and effectively as it should and could. Equally true is the fact that a malfunctioning system should not be turned back to a time when it was even less effective and less efficient, as the several commissions recommend. The reports suffer from ''a little more of the same'' syndrome derived from the belief that if two pills are good for the patient, four must be better.

results.snippet: ''What's the color got to do with it?'' asks Tom. ''It's got everything to do with it. Illinois is green, Indiana is pink. You show me any pink down here, if you can. No, sir; it's green.''   ''Indiana pink? Why, what a lie!'' ''It ain't no lie;...

byline.original: By John Noble Wilford; John Noble Wilford, who covers space and science for The Times, is the author of ''The Mapmakers.''

results.lead_paragraph: ''What's the color got to do with it?'' asks Tom. ''It's got everything to do with it. Illinois is green, Indiana is pink. You show me any pink down here, if you can. No, sir; it's green.'' ''Indiana pink? Why, what a lie!'' ''It ain't no lie; I've seen it on the map, and it's pink.'' This is too much for Tom. ''Seen it on the map! Huck Finn, did you reckon the states was the same color out of doors as they are on the map?''

results.snippet: Tsongas Due to Back Glenn   J ohn Glenn's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination is expected to get another lift Wednesday from the endorsement of fellow Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts.   Mr. Tsongas, a leader of the...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Tsongas Due to Back Glenn J ohn Glenn's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination is expected to get another lift Wednesday from the endorsement of fellow Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. Mr. Tsongas, a leader of the so-called Atari, or new wave Democratic liberals in the Senate, is believed to feel that Mr. Glenn is beginning to show that he is the Democrat best able to defeat President Reagan, or any other Republican, in 1984. His endorsement of Mr. Glenn was considered likely to vex the other Democratic candidates, especially former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, who suffers in some party circles from an old-fashioned liberal image, linked to President Carter and Hubert H. Humphrey. The endorsement of Mr. Glenn, the former astronaut from Ohio, comes at a time when opinion polls show him gaining on the other candidates. Reflecting the fine-edged calculating of primary campaigns, the expected Tsongas support was seen as significant because Massachusetts has an early primary and will send to the nominating convention the largest delegation from New England.

headline.main: AMERICANS IN SPACE: WOMEN ARE READY

results.snippet: HOUSTON   NEXT week - if all goes as planned - a new milestone in American space history will be reached when Sally Kristen Ride is lofted into space for nearly six days aboard the spaceship Challenger.   The decision by the National Aeronautics...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON NEXT week - if all goes as planned - a new milestone in American space history will be reached when Sally Kristen Ride is lofted into space for nearly six days aboard the spaceship Challenger. The decision by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to send the first American woman, a 32-year-old physicist, into space along with four male crewmen has been made despite long doubts, and what some might call prejudices, about the abilities of women to withstand the physical and psychological rigors of such an ordeal. ''No one could find any reason women could not fly,'' says Dr. Carolyn Huntoon, chief of NASA's biomedical laboratories. The NASA decision was based on tests and theoretical analyses done on the earth. Further questions now remain to be answered on the basis of actual flight in space: What is the best male-female balance among crew members? Will weightlessness have different effects on the muscle, cardiovascular, bone and hormonal systems in men and women? What are the psychological consequences of long-term isolation in small space? The forthcoming missions should begin to provide the answers.

results.snippet: SPACEMAN   Dr. Story Musgrave, who was out in space only two months ago aboard the Challenger STS-6 shuttle flight, will tell all about it at 1:30 P.M. today in a program at the American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West....

byline.original: By Richard F. Shepard

results.lead_paragraph: SPACEMAN Dr. Story Musgrave, who was out in space only two months ago aboard the Challenger STS-6 shuttle flight, will tell all about it at 1:30 P.M. today in a program at the American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West. The astronaut-physician, who walked in space, will appear in the museum's Naturemax Theater, itself an enormous space in which special films are shown on the city's largest indoor screen, one that is four stories tall. Before Dr. Musgrave speaks, the audience will be able to see ''Hail Columbia!'', a large-screen account of the first shuttle flight. The doctor, with slides and films made during his flight, will speak in nontechnical terms of his space voyage, telling how it felt to be whirling about the globe.

results.snippet: The New York Times Magazine's new weekly column, About Men, will address a broad range of male-related topics of interest to both sexes. The column will include essays, reportage, service pieces and advice on personal appearance. Nelson Bryant...

byline.original: By Nelson Bryant

results.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Magazine's new weekly column, About Men, will address a broad range of male-related topics of interest to both sexes. The column will include essays, reportage, service pieces and advice on personal appearance. Nelson Bryant writes the Outdoors column for The Times. IT WILL BE A LONG TIME BE-fore women make - should they choose to do so - a significant penetration into deer camps, the most sacrosanct gathering places of male hunters; but they have heard the call of the wild and are moving swiftly on other fronts. Asked by a woman if she may accompany you on your next fishing, hunting or canoeing trip, you can churlishly grunt, ''No way. Such things aren't for ladies.'' That, however, is a recreant's dodge and will leave her fuming, or - if your relationship has not been formalized into marriage - rejoicing that she discovered before it was too late the boor that lurked beneath the aura of quiet manhood that first attracted her, learned that still waters are often not deep but stagnant.

headline.main: GLENN SEEKING TO TURN A HERO'S IMAGE INTO VOTES

results.snippet: For a tiny moment, perhaps half a beat of that legendarily slow astronaut's pulse, Senator John Glenn seemed taken aback by the question. Then his normally squinty eyes narrowed even further with amusement.   ''I always thought,'' he announced into...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: For a tiny moment, perhaps half a beat of that legendarily slow astronaut's pulse, Senator John Glenn seemed taken aback by the question. Then his normally squinty eyes narrowed even further with amusement. ''I always thought,'' he announced into a plume of pipe smoke, ''that Ike was a very handsome man. Period.'' More to the point, Dwight D. Eisenhower was an avuncular, unthreatening leader who was able to transmute the loose change of an heroic image into the hard currency of political support. That is the task before Senator Glenn, and talk that he is trying to become a ''Democratic Eisenhower'' is heard often in Washington. For Senator Glenn, the question of whether he is trying to use Republican-style appeal in a party that already suspects him of excessive conservatism is a sensitive one. But if the Senator resorts to humorous evasions on this subject, his supporters and advisers do not. To them, his is a Democratic candidacy based in large part on the fact that he mirrors the strengths of successful Republican candidates, including President Eisenhower and President Reagan.

headline.main: COUNTDOWN STARTS FOR 2D LAUNCHING OF SHUTTLE CHALLENGER TOMORROW

results.snippet: Launching crews began the countdown today for the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger, which will carry two communications satellites, a score of scientific experiments, a colony of carpenter ants and the first American woman to go into...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Launching crews began the countdown today for the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger, which will carry two communications satellites, a score of scientific experiments, a colony of carpenter ants and the first American woman to go into space. Liftoff is scheduled for 7:33 A.M. Saturday, Eastern daylight time. The five astronauts, the largest crew to be launched, reviewed flight plans, checked equipment and practiced their flying skills in jet trainers as they prepared for the planned six-day mission. It will be the second flight of the Challenger, which was put in service last March, and the seventh shuttle flight.

results.snippet: Over the last several thousand years, the act of writing has moved through clay tablets and papyrus and parchment and through goose quills and ball point pens and electric typewriters. For a small group of novelists and screenwriters here, the act...

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Over the last several thousand years, the act of writing has moved through clay tablets and papyrus and parchment and through goose quills and ball point pens and electric typewriters. For a small group of novelists and screenwriters here, the act of writing now involves renting space on a computer in a small store in West Hollywood. For $10 an hour ($6 for the third consecutive hour) anyone can use one of the nine video display terminals at Wordplay. At least half a dozen professional writers have chosen to create or revise their scripts and novels there.

headline.main: SATELLITE TESTS TO HIGHLIGHT SHUTTLE FLIGHT

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger reviewed plans today for a flight on which they are to deploy two commercial satellites and, for the first time, release and retrieve a satellite using the shuttle's 50-foot mechanical arm.   The complicated...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger reviewed plans today for a flight on which they are to deploy two commercial satellites and, for the first time, release and retrieve a satellite using the shuttle's 50-foot mechanical arm. The complicated retrieval maneuver is to be done by Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman to fly in space. Barring last-minute malfunctions or bad weather, the astronauts were set to begin their orbital journey at 7:33 A.M. Saturday. Landing in Florida Planned The planned six-day mission, the nation's seventh shuttle flight, is also to include the operation of more than a score of scientific experiments.

results.snippet: This morning, at 7:33 Eastern daylight time, an astronaut named Ride is to fly the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger. The astronaut, who has a Ph.D. in physics, will act as flight engineer and will also launch two communications...
results.lead_paragraph: This morning, at 7:33 Eastern daylight time, an astronaut named Ride is to fly the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger. The astronaut, who has a Ph.D. in physics, will act as flight engineer and will also launch two communications satellites. Astronaut Ride calls the flight ''the experience of a lifetime.''

headline.main: COOL, VERSATILE ASTRONAUT: SALLY KRISTEN RIDE; W

results.snippet: The celebration over sending the first American woman into orbit has tended to overshadow the fact that Dr.  Sally K. Ride is to be the first person to perform one of the most significant tasks of the space age. Reaching into the void with a...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

results.lead_paragraph: The celebration over sending the first American woman into orbit has tended to overshadow the fact that Dr. Sally K. Ride is to be the first person to perform one of the most significant tasks of the space age. Reaching into the void with a 50-foot robotic arm, she plans to capture a satellite as it hurtles about the earth and, using mechanical might conferred by gears and motors, bring it safely to rest in the cargo bay of the space shuttle. Her aerial exercise points to the not-so-distant future when it could be routine to grasp satellites, mine asteroids, build space stations - in short, to clutch and shape instead of just to pass through space as an awestruck visitor. It marks a new stage in the taming of the high frontier.

results.snippet: THE PLACE IS JACKSON, Miss., and former Vice President Walter F.  Mondale is here to deliver a speech from the front steps of the Mississippi Governor's mansion. His performance is not unlike those he has given in 100 cities in 26 states between...

byline.original: By David Harris; David Harris is a frequent contributor to this magazine

results.lead_paragraph: THE PLACE IS JACKSON, Miss., and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is here to deliver a speech from the front steps of the Mississippi Governor's mansion. His performance is not unlike those he has given in 100 cities in 26 states between January and June of this year. A sprinkling of national press has come along to watch, and Mondale exhibits guarded ease. He is 55 years old and has no illusions about the process he must go through to win the Presidency. The reporters have come to examine his soft spots, and neither he nor they need to be told that the last two decades of Democratic Party history have been littered with the mistake-plagued wreckage of early front-runners.

results.snippet: Women who blazed trails in their own professions hailed the space mission of the astronaut Sally K. Ride yesterday as a giant leap for American women.   Elizabeth Hanford Dole and Margaret M. Heckler, members of the Cabinet; Beverly Sills, the...

byline.original: By United Press International

results.lead_paragraph: Women who blazed trails in their own professions hailed the space mission of the astronaut Sally K. Ride yesterday as a giant leap for American women. Elizabeth Hanford Dole and Margaret M. Heckler, members of the Cabinet; Beverly Sills, the director of the New York City Opera, and other women applauded as Dr. Ride, who is 32 years old, joined four men on a six-day mission aboard the space shuttle Challenger.

headline.main: SHUTTLE ROCKETS TO ORBIT WITH 5 ABOARD

results.snippet: Four men and a woman, the first American woman to go into space, rocketed into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Challenger and then launched the first of two satellites in the successful beginning of a busy six-day mission.   The winged...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Four men and a woman, the first American woman to go into space, rocketed into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Challenger and then launched the first of two satellites in the successful beginning of a busy six-day mission. The winged spaceship lifted off on schedule at 7:33 A.M. after one of the smoothest countdowns of the shuttle program. It carried two communications satellites, an assortment of scientific experiments and a West German satellite that is to be released and then retrieved in a critical test of the shuttle's 50-foot mechanical arm. On future missions astronauts expect to release small satellites with the mechanical arm and to rendezvous with ailing satellites to retrieve them for repairs in orbit or back on the earth.

headline.main: SKETCHES OF THE FOUR MEN OF THE CHALLENGER'S CREW

results.snippet: Robert Crippen   Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy is the first astronaut to fly aboard an American shuttle twice. This time he got a promotion. After almost 14 years as an astronaut, the pilot of the Columbia's first flight in April 1981 has...

byline.original: By BRYCE NELSON

results.lead_paragraph: Robert Crippen Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy is the first astronaut to fly aboard an American shuttle twice. This time he got a promotion. After almost 14 years as an astronaut, the pilot of the Columbia's first flight in April 1981 has achieved his desire to command a space flight. The flight commander is clearly overshadowed in public attention by Sally K. Ride, but when a reporter told him Texans did not think a woman could do an astronaut's job, Captain Crippen, a native Texan, bristled.

headline.main: ODIZOR OF NIGERIA TOPS VILAS IN 5 SETS

results.snippet: Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc, missing from last year's Wimbledon tennis championships because of Argentina's war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, were eliminated on the tournament's opening day today.   A 24-year-old Nigerian, Nduka...

byline.original: By NEIL AMDUR, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc, missing from last year's Wimbledon tennis championships because of Argentina's war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, were eliminated on the tournament's opening day today. A 24-year-old Nigerian, Nduka Odizor, playing his first centercourt match ever in a Grand Slam event, saved a match point from two sets down in a third-set tiebreaker and then outlasted the fourthseeded Vilas in a 4-hour-7-minute marathon. The scores were 3-6, 5-7, 7-6, 7-5, 6-2. Odizor's amazing saga began as a promising 15-year-old player in Lagos. Discovered by an American college professor, he was encouraged to continue his education in the United States, was graduated with a degree in marketing from the University of Houston in 1981 and is now ranked 82d on the men's computer rankings.

headline.main: CHALLENGER, PASSING ITS TESTS, PREPARES TO CATCH A SATELLITE

results.snippet: Scientific experiments on a West German satellite were switched on and tested today as the Challenger astronauts prepared for the next major event of the space shuttle mission - the first deployment and retrieval of an orbiting satellite.   Early...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Scientific experiments on a West German satellite were switched on and tested today as the Challenger astronauts prepared for the next major event of the space shuttle mission - the first deployment and retrieval of an orbiting satellite. Early Wednesday morning, as now planned, the astronauts are to pick up the 5,000-pound satellite with the shuttle's robotic arm, drop it out of the cargo bay, fly as much as 1,000 feet away from it and then go back and, again using the 50-foot-long arm, retrieve it for restowage in the cargo bay. This operation, the first major test of the many-jointed mechanical arm, is considered an important rehearsal for future missions when space shuttles will be called on to rendezvous with satellites for servicing and repairs. Flight controllers said the Challenger and its five-person crew continued to make space flight look easy, with the health of both the machine and the astronauts reported to be excellent. Their six-day mission is scheduled to end Friday morning with a landing at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

results.snippet: ''MY dream ever since I was a little boy was to be a milkman,'' Stew Leonard recalls, leaning back in a chair in his office here.  ''My family was in the dairy business that's what I knew best and it's all I wanted.'' To say that Mr. Leonard has...

byline.original: By BRYAN MILLER

results.lead_paragraph: ''MY dream ever since I was a little boy was to be a milkman,'' Stew Leonard recalls, leaning back in a chair in his office here. ''My family was in the dairy business that's what I knew best and it's all I wanted.'' To say that Mr. Leonard has realized his dream is somewhat like saying the astronaut Neil Armstrong made good on a boyhood fantasy of flying an airplane. Mr. Leonard sells 10 million quarts of milk a year, not to mention a million pints of cream, a million cartons of yogurt, 100 tons of cottage cheese, a million dozen eggs and equally staggering quantities of 600 other products. He has not driven a delivery truck since the late 1960's, when the state of Connecticut furrowed a highway through his dairy farm. But Mr. Leonard says he remains essentially a milkman - perhaps the most successful one in America.

headline.main: RETRIEVAL TESTING DUE IN ORBIT TODAY

results.snippet: The Challenger astronauts are preparing the way for space shuttle operations of a new dimension, in which crews could be going forth regularly to grab satellites in orbit for refueling, repairs or a return to earth.   This was the import of an...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger astronauts are preparing the way for space shuttle operations of a new dimension, in which crews could be going forth regularly to grab satellites in orbit for refueling, repairs or a return to earth. This was the import of an exercise set for Wednesday morning: the deployment and retrieval of a satellite 181 miles out in space. Success would encourage officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to accelerate preparations for an ambitious mission next April to repair a scientific satellite that has been crippled since late 1980. They hoped a success would also inspire new designs for future spacecraft to facilitate maintenance by attending shuttles.

results.snippet: The space shuttle Challenger engaged in a stately minuet with a satellite today, going round and round the world in a sequence of careful new celestial maneuvers.   The Challenger released a West German scientific satellite into space, followed it,...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Challenger engaged in a stately minuet with a satellite today, going round and round the world in a sequence of careful new celestial maneuvers. The Challenger released a West German scientific satellite into space, followed it, glided around it, then plucked it back out of the void with the spaceship's long robotic arm. In successfully completing the task, the Challenger's astronauts demonstrated an important new capability, the ability to retrieve satellites that may need maintenance or repair. Five times the astronauts released the 15-foot-long, Shuttle Pallet Satellite, or SPAS, which weighs 3,200 pounds on earth. Five times the astronauts, particularly Dr. Sally K. Ride and Col. John M. Fabian of the Air Force, operated the multijointed arm to grapple a fixture on the satellite and retrieve it.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE: A MISSING AMERICAN RIGHT

results.snippet: To the Editor:    Equality before the law is a well-established concept. Equal opportunity for education has been affirmed by the Supreme Court, noting it is intimately interwoven with the basic American expectations for the quality of life. Isn't...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Equality before the law is a well-established concept. Equal opportunity for education has been affirmed by the Supreme Court, noting it is intimately interwoven with the basic American expectations for the quality of life. Isn't it about time that all our citizens enjoyed equal access to high-quality medical care?

results.snippet: She learned to fly a biplane when she was 12 years old, and by 18 she was an accomplished licensed pilot. In early 1960, at 29, she became the first woman to pass all the grueling physical and psychological tests that the National Aeronautics and...

byline.original: By Richard Haitch

results.lead_paragraph: She learned to fly a biplane when she was 12 years old, and by 18 she was an accomplished licensed pilot. In early 1960, at 29, she became the first woman to pass all the grueling physical and psychological tests that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration gave to aspiring astronauts.

headline.main: SOVIET CRAFT LAUNCHED IN NEW LINKUP ATTEMPT

results.snippet: A Soyuz spacecraft commanded by an astronaut who once held the record for the longest space flight was lifted into orbit today to make the second attempt in two months to link up with the Salyut 7 space station.   ''The rocket's going steadily,''...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: A Soyuz spacecraft commanded by an astronaut who once held the record for the longest space flight was lifted into orbit today to make the second attempt in two months to link up with the Salyut 7 space station. ''The rocket's going steadily,'' the mission commander, Vladimir Lyakhov, was quoted as saying as Soyuz 9 and its two-member crew went into orbit this afternoon after the spacecraft was launched from the Baikonur space center in Central Asia. Mr. Lyakhov and the flight engineer, Aleksandr Aleksandrov, who is making his first voyage in space, were to dock with Salyut 7 and Cosmos 1443, a supply craft that linked with the orbiting space station in April.

results.snippet: Out of High School And Right Into College   T hey were invited for a ''curbside barbecue,'' befitting a city campus, but the lunch-hour rain drove members of New York University's class of 1987 indoors for their first mixer yesterday.   Some of the...

byline.original: By Laurie Johnston and Susan Heller Anderson

results.lead_paragraph: Out of High School And Right Into College T hey were invited for a ''curbside barbecue,'' befitting a city campus, but the lunch-hour rain drove members of New York University's class of 1987 indoors for their first mixer yesterday. Some of the 1,200 freshmen are entering with the summer term.

results.snippet: Blacks in Aviation: Space Age and Before   T his summer, the space shuttle is scheduled to carry the first black astronaut - Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. of the Air Force - into space. For the occasion, the Hayden Planetarium is presenting...

byline.original: By Laurie Johnston and Susan Heller Anderson

results.lead_paragraph: Blacks in Aviation: Space Age and Before T his summer, the space shuttle is scheduled to carry the first black astronaut - Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. of the Air Force - into space. For the occasion, the Hayden Planetarium is presenting ''Black Wings: The American Black in Aviation,'' an exhibition organized by the Smithsonian Institution.
